questions.text: Mr.Anil has recently undergone a kidney transplant. He is started on a calcineurin inhibitor which belongs to the macrolide class of antibiotics. Which of the following levels will you monitor in such a patient?
questions.solution:
• The above question describes Tacrolimus, which is a macrolide antibiotic but has the same mechanism of action as Cyclosporine. It binds to FK 506binding protein (FKBP) and inhibits
  • Th cells via calcineurin. It is more potent than cyclosporine and is thus preferred for GVHD, organ transplant etc.
  • Hypertension, hirsutism, gum hyperplasia and hyperuricemia are less marked than with cyclosporine, but tacrolimus is more likely to precipitate diabetes, cause neurotoxicity, alopecia
  • and diarrhea. Dose limiting toxicity is renal.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 940-941

questions.text:
A 24-year-old woman presented to the hematology clinic with a history of easy nontraumatic bruising on both thighs and legs. She had a recent history of fall, with bruises on the left hip, bilateral arms, and the lower left quadrant of the abdomen. She denied any bleeding gums, pain in joints or any bleeding into joints, heavy menstrual blood flow, nasal bleeds, blood in stool, or blood in urine. The physical examination was unremarkable except for few bruises on bilateral thighs.
Her blood profile is as follows
Hemoglobin 12.3 g/dl (10.5-13.5)
Hematocrit 35.4% (33.0-39.0)
WBC 7.9 x 10^9/L (6.0-17.5)
Platelets 368 x 10^9/L (156-369)
PT 11.3 s (10.0-12.8)
APTT 37.2 s (24.4-33.2)

What class of drug is preferred to manage this condition?
questions.solution:
• The above clinical vignette describes von Willebrand disease which presents with varying degrees of bleeding tendency, usually in the form of easy bruising, nosebleeds, and bleeding gums People may experience heavy menstrual periods and blood loss during childbirth
  • Severe internal bleeding and bleeding into joints are uncommon in all but the most severe type, VWD type 3.
  • When VWD is suspected, blood plasma of a patient must be investigated for quantitative and qualitative deficiencies of VWF. This is achieved by measuring the amount of VWF in a VWF antigen assay and the functionality of VWF with a glycoprotein (GP)Ib binding assay, a collagen binding assay, or a ristocetin cofactor activity (RiCof) or ristocetin-induced platelet agglutination (RIPA) assays. Factor VIII levels are also performed because factor VIII is bound to VWF which protects the factor VIII from rapid breakdown within the blood. Deficiency of VWF can then lead to a reduction in factor VIII levels, which explains the elevation in PTT.
  • The drug of choice for managing this condition is Desmopressin, which is a selective V2 agonist. It induces secretion of VWF from endothelial cells by binding to V2 receptors on cell membranes and by activating cyclic adenosine monophosphate (c-AMP)-mediated signaling.

Reference:

Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 643

questions.text: A novice mountaineer was to begin a steep ascent. He was made aware that rapid ascent to high altitudes may produce mountain sickness, which may cause headache, nausea, giddiness etc. Acute mountain sickness may also lead to pulmonary or cerebral edema. Thus, to prevent such symptoms, he began prophylaxis with a diuretic that inhibits carbonic anhydrase. What would be the effect of this drug on the acid base balance of the body?
questions.solution:
• The drug being described here is Acetazolamide, which provides both symptomatic as well as prophylactic benefit in mountain sickness.
  • When CAse inhibitors are given, the distal Na+ exchange takes place only with K+ which is lost in excess.
  • For the same degree of natriuresis Case inhibitors cause the most marked kaliuresis compared to other diuretics.
  • The urine produced under acetazolamide action is alkaline and rich in HCO3 which is matched by both Na+ and K+.
  • Continued action of acetazolamide depletes body HCO3 and causes acidosis.

Reference:

Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 633

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of inotrope Levosimendan?
questions.solution:
• Levosimendan acts by sensitizing myocardial troponin C to Ca2+, as well as by inhibiting PDE3.
  • As such,the inotropic effect occurs even in patients receiving blockers, and is not associated with a change in cytosolic Ca2+ concentration. It also opens ATPsensitive K channels in vascular smooth muscle cells to cause vasodilatation.
  • Thus, it is another ‘inodilator', Haemo dynamic improvement in heart failure is both due to increase in cardiac contractility as well as reduction in preload and afterload.
  • Levosimendan infused i.v. is primarily indicated for short term treatment of acutely decompensated severe chronic heart failure.
  • Direct myosin stimulator is Omecamtiv Mecarbil

Reference:

Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 568

questions.text: Manorama, a 30-year-old woman was on oral digoxin prophylaxis for chronic atrial fibrillation. She came to the OPD with complaints of fever which developed every 72 hours, chills and headache for 3 days. Her blood smear was positive for P.Vivax malaria. She was prescribed quinidine for the same for 5 days. However, on the second day, she developed nausea, vomiting. Her ECG showed ventricular bigeminy. What is the reason for her new symptoms?
questions.solution:
• Nausea, vomiting are the earliest features of digoxin toxicity. The characteristic arrhythmia seen in its toxicity is ventricular bigeminy.
  • Quinidine causes digoxin toxicity by inhibiting p-gp pump, which ejects digoxin and terminates its action.
  • Mild digoxin toxicity can be treated by K+ injection, whereas V.Tach due to digoxin is treated with Lidocaine.
  • Digoxin antibody, or digibind can also be used to treat digoxin toxicity.

Reference:

Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 561

questions.text: Reyansh, a 68-year-old man, had been diagnosed with essential hypertension 15 years ago, for which he was started on Telmisartan and Nifedipine. Since the past 1 month, he has had urinary problems in the form of increased frequency, incomplete voiding and nocturia. A PR revealed an enlarged prostate, which was confirmed by serum PSA levels. Which antihypertensive may be added to his prescription, which has a therapeutic effect on BPH?
questions.solution:
• Prazosin is a selective alpha-1 antagonist that dilates resistance and capacitance vessels and thus reduces total peripheral resistance and mean BP. It causes minimum reflex tachycardia since inhibitory alpha-2 receptors are not blocked.
  • Side effects include first dose hypotension; thus, it is started at the lowest possible dose. It is currently not used as a first line antihypertensive, but more as an add on, especially in BPH, where it has a therapeutic effect on the dynamic component of BPH by inhibiting alpha receptors on the sphincter.

Reference:

Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 611

questions.text: Aamna, a 23-year-old woman presents with headache, nausea, epigastric discomfort and visual problems. She is 25 weeks pregnant, and her obstetric score is G1P0A0L0. Her vitals reveal a BP of 158/106 mmHg. She does not have a previous history of hypertension. She is immediately admitted to the ward. Her dipstick is positive for +2 proteinuria. Fundoscopy reveals papilledema. What is the preferred antihypertensive in this case?
questions.solution:
• The clinical vignette above describes pre-eclampsia with impending seizures. Convulsions are prevented by giving MgSO4. Antihypertensive of choice in PIH/PE is oral labetalol. I.V labetalol is given in hypertensive crisis. Labetalol is also given in Pheochromocytoma, stroke and IHD. it is contraindicated in CHF.
  • ACEI like lisinopril and Diuretics like Indapamide are contraindicated in pregnancy.
  • Other drugs safe in pregnancy are-
    • Beta blockers such as labetalol for Pre-eclampsia and Eclampsia
    • Clonidine
    • DHP-CCB'
    • Hydralazine
    • Prazosin

Reference:

Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 620

questions.text: Which of the following second line anti-anginal act as anti-metabolites and reduce the O2 demand of the heart?
questions.solution:
• The mechanism of action of trimetazidine is uncertain, but it may improve cellular tolerance to ischemia by modulating myocardial metabolism.
  • It has been shown to inhibit the mitochondrial long chain 3-ketoacyl-CoA thiolase (LC3-KAT), a key enzyme in fatty acid oxidation.
  • It thus reduces fatty acid oxidation and promotes glucose oxidation in myocardium.
  • Ischemic myocardium shifts to utilizing fatty acid as substrate, thereby increasing the requirement of O2 for the same amount of ATP generated.
  • Since oxidation of fatty acid requires more O2, shift back of substrate to glucose would reduce O2 demand.
  • Trimetazidine has been labelled as pFOx (fatty acid oxidation pathway) inhibitor.
  • There is no effect on determinants of myocardial O2 consumption, such as HR and BP, both at rest as well as during exercise, but angina frequency is reduced and exercise capacity is increased. In patients not adequately controlled by long-acting nitrate or β blocker or CCB, addition of trimetazidine further reduced anginal attacks and increased exercise duration.
  • Trimetazidine is absorbed orally, partly metabolized and largely excreted unchanged in urine; t1⁄2 is 6 hr. It is generally well tolerated; side effects are-gastric burning, dizziness, fatigue and muscle cramps. Reversible parkinsonism has been reported in the elderly.
  • Other options-
    • Fasudil is a rhokinase inhibitor
    • Nicorandil is a potassium channel opener
    • Riociguat is a soluble guanylate cyclase stimulator

Reference:

Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 599

questions.text: A 49-year-old male, who is a chronic smoker smoking 2 packs since 15 years presents with complaints of calf pain while walking. His symptoms began 2 months ago. Initially, the pain would subside after 2 minutes of walking and later it progressed to pain that did not subside with activity and forced him to rest. Doppler studies were done and a provisional diagnosis of peripheral vascular disease, Berger's disease was made. Aside from smoking cessation, the patient was prescribed pentoxifylline. By which mechanism does it alleviate the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
• Pentoxiphylline is a theophylline analogue which has been shown to increase blood flow in ischemic areas by reducing whole blood viscosity and by improving flexibility of RBCs. The rheological (dealing with property of flow) action rather than vasodilatation is said to be responsible for improving passage of blood through microcirculation. Oral doses do not affect heart rate, total peripheral resistance or BP.
  • Pentoxiphylline is usually well tolerated: side effects are nausea, vomiting, dyspepsia and bloating which can be minimized by taking the drug after meals.
  • Pentoxiphylline is mainly used in intermittent claudication (calf pain on walking) due to occlusive vascular disease (Berger's disease).

Reference:

Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 601

questions.text: A 27-year-old had just gotten fired from his job. He was on medication for depression for 7 years but had forgotten his medication that day. Under extreme stress he decided to commit suicide by consuming baygon. He was later found by his flat mate, and was brought to the ER. He was hypotensive, tachycardic and was convulsing. He also had miosis and increased secretions. Which of the following resuscitation measures should not be followed in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Baygon (Propoxur) belongs to irreversibly acting carbamates, which are anti AchE class of drugs.
  • Pralidoxime is ineffective as an antidote to carbamate antiChEs (physostigmine, neostigmine, carbaryl, propoxur) in which case the anionic site of the enzyme is not free to provide attachment to it. It is rather contraindicated in carbamate poisoning, because not only it does not reactivate carbamylated enzymes, it has weak antiChE activity of its own.
  • Anticholinesterases are easily available and extensively used as agricultural and household insecticides; accidental as well as suicidal and homicidal poisoning is common.
  • Local muscarinic manifestations at the site of exposure (skin, eye, g.i.t.) occur immediately and are followed by complex systemic effects due to muscarinic, nicotinic and central actions. They are-
    • Irritation of eye, lacrimation, salivation, sweating, copious tracheobronchial secretions, miosis, blurring of vision, bronchospasm, breathlessness, colic, involuntary defecation and urination.
    • Fall in BP, bradycardia or tachycardia, cardiac arrhythmias, vascular collapse.
    • Muscular fasciculations, weakness, respiratory paralysis (central as well as peripheral).
    • Irritability, disorientation, unsteadiness, tremor, ataxia, convulsions, coma and death.
    • Death is generally due to respiratory failure.
  • Treatment-
  1. Termination of further exposure to the poison-fresh air, wash the skin and mucous membranes with soap and water, gastric lavage according to need.
  2. Maintain patent airway, positive pressure respiration if it is failing.
  3. Supportive measures-maintain BP, hydration, control of convulsions with judicious use of diazepam.
  4. Specific antidotes-

(a) Atropine It is highly effective in counteracting the muscarinic symptoms, but higher doses are required to antagonize the central effects. It does not reverse peripheral muscular paralysis which is a nicotinic action. All cases of antiChE (carbamate or organophosphate) poisoning must be promptly given atropine

2 mg i.v. repeated every 10 min till dryness of mouth or other signs of atropinization appear (upto 200 mg has been administered in a day). Continued treatment with maintenance doses may be required for 1-2 weeks.

(b) Cholinesterase reactivators Oximes are used to restore neuromuscular transmission only in case of organophosphate antiChE poisoning.

Reference:

Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 122

questions.text:
The drug of choice for motion sickness is hyoscine, which is an anticholinergic. To which of the following patients can this drug not be prescribed?
1. A 69-year-old male having BPH
2. A 32-year-old lady with Depression taking SSRI's
3. A 14-year-old having a flat iridocorneal angle
4. A 5-year-old on imipramine for urinary incontinence
5. A 21-year-old on latanoprost therapy for open angle glaucoma
questions.solution:
• Hyoscine and atropine drugs, which are para-sympatholytic, are contraindicated in patients with a narrow iridocorneal angle to avoid angle closure glaucoma and in patients of BPH to avoid urinary retention.
  • They are however, not contraindicated in open angle glaucoma
  • They are also not given with TCA's (like Imipramine), antihistamines, phenothiazines and pethidine, since their drugs have anticholinergic properties of their own and thus may cause additive side effects with Atropine Drugs.

Reference:

Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 132

questions.text: A patient experiencing diplopia and ptosis and muscle fatigability which worsened with exercise was on pyridostigmine therapy. He later presented with a bacterial infection for which a broad-spectrum antibiotic was to be prescribed. Which of the following anti-bacterials cannot be prescribed to the patient keeping his co-morbidity in mind?
questions.solution:
Neuromuscular blockade

All aminoglycosides reduce ACh release from the motor nerve endings. They interfere with mobilization of centrally located synaptic vesicles to fuse with the terminal membrane (probably by antagonizing Ca2+) as well as decrease the sensitivity of the muscle end-plates to ACh. Rapid absorption form the peritoneum/pleura produces high blood levels and adds to the residual action of the neuromuscular blocker.

The neuromuscular block produced by aminoglycosides can be partially antagonized by i.v. injection of a calcium salt. Neostigmine has inconsistent reversing action. Myasthenic weakness is accentuated by these drugs.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 795

questions.text: A child is diagnosed to have ADHD. He is prescribed methylphenidate. By what mechanism does this drug improve the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
• Methylphenidate is the DOC for ADHD. it is an Indirectly acting sympathomimetic.
  • These drugs act by increasing the release of NA in the synaptic cleft or by inhibiting the reuptake of NA.
  • These agents enter the neuronal cytoplasm by the same transporter that is responsible for the reuptake of NA.
  • From the cytoplasm, these drugs enter the storage vesicles and displace and release the stored NA (because each vesicle has fixed storage capacity). Released NA activates adrenergic receptors.
  • On repeated dosing at short intervals, tachyphylaxis (rapid development of tolerance) is seen with these drugs.

Reference:

Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 151

questions.text: A 59-year-old has been having visual difficulty over the past few months, and lately she had started noticing 'halos' around the lights. She also has dull chronic ache in the forehead region and reports a change in the power of her glasses thrice over a period of 6 months. Tonometry revealed her intraocular pressure (i.o.p.) to be 22- and 24-mm Hg respectively in the left and right eye. Accordingly, she was started on topical therapy with a drug that increases uveoscleral outflow. However, on follow-up, she revealed to have been experiencing blurring of vision. Her FFA revealed 'smoke stack pattern' and her OCT findings are given below. Which drug could have been prescribed to her that could cause this finding in the patient?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical vignette describes primary open angle glaucoma and the adverse effect depicted here is Cystoid macular Edema (CME).
  • The drug of choice for POAG are PGF2α analogues, such as Latanoprost and Bimatoprost.
  • Low concentration of PGF2α was found to lower i.o.t without inducing ocular inflammation. It acts by increasing uveoscleral outflow, possibly by increasing permeability of tissues in ciliary muscle or by an action on episcleral vessels. An effect on trabecular outflow has also been demonstrated, but is less marked. Ciliary body COX2 has been found to be down regulated in wide angle glaucoma indicating a physiological role of PGs in aqueous humor dynamics. PGF2α analogues are known to cause CME, especially in aphakic patients.
  • Other side effects include iris hyperpigmentation and thickening of eyelashes
  • Timolol is a beta blocker that causes blepharoconjunctivitis as an adverse effect/
  • Brimonidine is a clonidine congener that can cause CNS depression in children, in whom it is contraindicated

Reference:

Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 169

questions.text: A full term primigravida aged 26 years is brought to the hospital with the complaint of having labor pains for the past 24 hours without making much progress. Two hours ago, she passed meconium-stained liquor. The lady is in distress, mildly dehydrated and looks exhausted. The presentation is vertex and head are engaged, but cervix is incompletely dilated and uterine contractions are relatively weak. Fetal tachycardia is noted with irregularity during contraction. The woman is started on oxytocin infusion. Which adverse effect is to be monitored for when this drug is being infused?
questions.solution:
Adverse effects of oxytocin

  • Injudicious use of oxytocin during labour can produce too strong uterine contractions forcing the presenting part through incompletely dilated birth canal, causing maternal and foetal soft tissue injury, rupture of uterus, foetal asphyxia and death.
  • Water intoxication: This occurs due to ADH like action of large doses given along with i.v. fluids, especially in toxaemia of pregnancy and renal insufficiency. It is a serious (may be fatal) complication.

Reference:

Essential of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 356

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman has delivered her first daughter. She now wishes to space her pregnancy for 3 years and asks her doctor to prescribe her Oral Contraceptive Pills for the same. Before prescribing the same, which of these is not necessary to be checked?
questions.solution:
The combined oral contraceptive pill is absolutely contraindicated in:

  1. Thromboembolic, coronary and cerebrovascular disease or a history of it.
  2. Moderate to Severe hypertension; hyperlipidemia.
  3. Active liver disease, hepatoma or h/o jaundice during past pregnancy.
  4. Suspected/overt malignancy of genitals/breast.
  5. Porphyria.
  6. Impending major surgery-to avoid excess risk of postoperative thromboembolism. Estrogen

containing contraceptive should be stopped 4 weeks before surgery.

Relative contraindications (requiring avoidance/cautious use under supervision)

  1. Diabetes: control may be vitiated.
  2. Obesity
  3. Smoking
  4. Undiagnosed vaginal bleeding
  5. Uterine leiomyoma: may enlarge with estrogenic preparations; progestin only pills can be used.
  6. Mentally ill
  7. Age above 35 years
  8. Mild hypertension
  9. Migraine
  10. Gallbladder disease.

Reference:

Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 352

choices.text: It is useful for the dynamic component of BPH
It inhibits both type-1 and type-2 5-alpha reductase
It can be used for Male pattern baldness as well
The beneficial effects are delayed for maximum symptomatic relief

questions.text: Mr.Mahek is on treatment for BPH. He has been prescribed Dutasteride and Terazosin for the same. Which of the following is incorrect about Dutasteride?
questions.solution:
• Dutasteride is a newer congener of finasteride inhibits both type 1 and type 2 5α­reductase
  • and reduces DHT levels. It is metabolized by CYP3A4 and is very long-acting (t1⁄2 is ~ 9
  • weeks).
  • It is approved for use in BHP and can benefit male pattern baldness.
  • In clinical
  • trias, both finasteride and dutasteride have been found to reduce the risk of developing carcinoma prostate by upto 25%.
  • Interactions with CYP3A4 inducers and inhibitors are possible.
  • The beneficial effects are typically delayed needing ~6 months for maximum symptomatic relief.
  • Patients with a large prostate (volume > 40 ml) obtain greater relief than those with smaller gland. Upto 20% reduction in prostate size may be obtained.
  • It primarily reduces the static component of obstruction, while α1 blockers overcome the dynamic component.

Reference:

Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 327

questions.text: A 59-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with Colle's fracture. She attained menopause 6 years ago. Her z score is -3SD. She is to be started on a drug for osteoporosis that both stimulates bone formation and inhibits bone resorption. Which of the following may be prescribed?
questions.solution:
• Strontium Ranelate is an organic compound of strontium that inhibits bone resorption by preventing osteoclast differentiation and promoting their apoptosis.
  • In addition, it stimulates bone formation.
  • In clinical trials it has been found to increase bone mineral density and to decrease the risk of vertebral as well as hip fracture.
  • However, it can increase the risk of serious cardiovascular disease like MI, stroke and thromboembolism.
  • Therefore, it is indicated only as a reserve drug for severe osteoporosis


Reference:

Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 372

questions.text: A 41-year-old diabetic was on treatment with a certain drug for 5 years. On regular follow-up, he reported fatigue and knuckle hyperpigmentation for 1 month. He is also a strict vegetarian. On examination, generalized pallor and a glossy magenta tongue was noted. His Hb was 9gm% and his peripheral smear showed the following. What is the mechanism of action of the OHA causing this adverse effect?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical vignette and the image showing hyper-segmented neutrophils suggests B12 deficiency anemia, which is a known adverse effect of Metformin, which is a biguanide.
  • Though the details are not clear, recent studies have recognized activation of AMP dependent protein kinase (AMPK) to play a crucial role in mediating the actions of metformin, the key features of which are:
    • Suppresses hepatic gluconeogenesis and glucose output from liver.
    • Enhances insulin mediated glucose uptake and disposal in skeletal muscle and fat. Insulin resistance exhibited by type2 diabetics is thus overcome.
    • This translates into-

- glycogen storage in skeletal muscle

reduced lipogenesis in adipose tissue and enhanced fatty acid oxidation.

  • Interferes with mitochondrial respiratory chain and promotes peripheral glucose utilization through anaerobic glycolysis.
  • Metformin also retards intestinal absorption of glucose, other hexoses, amino acids and Vit B12, which explains B12 deficiency anemia associated with high doses of metformin
  • Other options-
    • PPAR-gamma activators are thiazolidinediones, which cause CHF and weight gain
    • Alpha-glucosidase inhibitor is acarbose, which causes flatulence
    • ATP Sensitive potassium channel blockers are Sulfonylureas and meglitinides


    Reference:

    Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 299

choices.text: Decrease the dose and increase gradually

questions.text:
A 28-year-old sex worker presented with the lesion given below, which later progressed to a gumma.

VDRL test was found positive and the patient was started on Benzathine penicillin for Secondary syphilis. However, after the first dose, the patient developed fever, chills and arthralgia and there was a marked worsening of the cutaneous lesions. What should be the further course of action with respect to the therapy?
questions.solution:
• The clinical vignette above suggests Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction.
  • Penicillin injected in a syphilitic patient (particularly secondary syphilis) may produce shivering, fever, myalgia, exacerbation of lesions, even vascular collapse.
  • This is due to sudden release of spirochetal lytic products. It does not recur and does not need interruption of therapy. Aspirin and sedation afford relief of symptoms.

Reference:

Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 770

questions.text: A 15-year-old child with rice water diarrhea and dehydration was prescribed tetracycline. This class of drug is not used for treatment of which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
• Tetracyclines, especially demeclocycline is a V-2 receptor inhibitor, thus it causes DI and is not used for its treatment. However, another Tetracycline known as demeclocycline is used for treatment of SIADH.
  • Minocycline is used for treatment of nodulocystic acne as well as a second line in Leprosy

Reference:

Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 789

questions.text: A 47-year-old experiencing recurrent episodes of furuncles on skin was found to be a staphylococcal nasal carrier. Accordingly, he was prescribed a topical ointment that inhibits t-RNA synthase. Which of the following could have been prescribed?
questions.solution:
• Mupirocin is a topical antibiotic which is the drug of choice for staphylococcal nasal carriers. It inhibits bacterial t-RNA synthase.
  • Other uses include impetigo and gram-positive infections
  • Lefamulin is a pleuromotilin, which is used for resistant CAP
  • Fidaxomicin is an RNA polymerase inhibitor, which is used for Vancomycin resistant Enterocolitis
  • Chloramphenicol is a transpeptidation inhibitor, which is used for meningitis and severe rickettsial infections.

Reference:

Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 809

questions.text:
A 25-year-old sex worker presented with weight loss of more than 10 kg in 6 months, recurrent diarrhea and recently developed oral thrush. Her RTPCR was positive for HIV infection. Accordingly, she was to be started on ART. Her blood reports are as follows-
Hb-8.1g%
WBC-10,000/dL
Platelets- 1.5 lakh/mm3
CD4 cell count- 250cells/uL
According to this report which Antiretroviral will you not prescribe to this patient?
questions.solution:
• The blood picture above shows anemia. Anemia and neutropenia are adverse effects seen maximum with the NRTI Zidovudine and thus it is contraindicated in these conditions.
  • Stavudine is a NRTI causing peripheral neuropathy
  • Dolutegravir is an integrase inhibitor
  • Indinavir is a protease inhibitor causing crystalluria and nephrolithiasis.

Adverse effects of Zidovudin

Anaemia and neutropenia are the most important and dose-related adverse effects.

Nausea, anorexia, abdominal pain, headache, insomnia and myalgia are common at the start of therapy, but diminish later. Myopathy, pigmentation of nails, lactic acidosis, hepatomegaly are infrequent.

Reference:

Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 861

questions.text: A 20-year-old developed fever, chills and shivering during the monsoon season. The fever spikes were seen every 48 hours. The patient's blood report was significant for thrombocytopenia. Her peripheral smear revealed the following. Accordingly, a gametocide anti-plasmodial agent was to be given. Before administering the drug, the patient's physician asked for a certain blood test to be performed. Which of the following could it be?
questions.solution:
• The given vignette along with the peripheral smear is suggestive of Plasmodium Falciparum malaria.
  • Primaquine, which is a gametocide, is one of the drugs preferred for this condition.
  • Unlike other antimalarial drugs, primaquine is a poor erythrocytic schizonticide. It has weak action on P. vivax, but blood forms of P. falciparum are totally insensitive.
  • On the other hand, it is more active against the pre erythrocytic stage of P. falciparum.
  • Primaquine differs from all other available antimalarials in having a marked effect on primary as well as secondary hepatic phases of the malarial parasite. It is highly active against gametocytes and hypnozoites.
  • The mechanism of action of primaquine is not precisely known, but the reactive intermediate metabolites of primaquine are believed to generate intra-parasitic toxic oxidative species which disrupt the electron transport in plasmodial mitochondria.
  • The most important toxic potential is dose related hemolysis, methemoglobinemia, tachypnoea and cyanosis.
  • These effects are due to the oxidant property of primaquine. Its metabolites are more potent in this regard.
  • However, in normal individuals' doses < 60 mg (base) produce little hemolysis. Those with G-6-PD deficiency are highly susceptible, and hemolytic anemia can occur with 15-30 mg/day.
  • There are several variants of G-6-PD deficiency, and the defect is graded. Massive hemolysis is associated only with the 'Mediterranean' and few other variants.

Reference:

Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 885

questions.text: Pinky was experiencing dysuria, itching and greenish discharge from her vagina. On per speculum examination, a 'strawberry cervix was seen'. Saline microscopy revealed Trichomonas species. She was appropriately started on the drug of choice for the condition. On which of the following bacterial infections does this drug have no effect?
questions.solution:
• The drug of choice for Trichomonas vaginitis is Metronidazole.
  • After entering the cell by diffusion, its nitro group is reduced by certain redox proteins operative only in anaerobic microbes to a highly reactive nitro radical which exerts cytotoxicity.
  • The nitro radical of metronidazole acts as an electron sink which competes with the biological electron acceptors of the anaerobic organism for the electrons generated by the pyruvate: ferredoxin oxidoreductase (PFOR) enzyme pathway of pyruvate oxidation.
  • The energy metabolism of anaerobes that have no mitochondria is thus disrupted. Aerobic environment attenuates cytotoxicity of metronidazole by inhibiting its reductive activation.
  • Moreover, O2 competes with the nitro radical of metronidazole for the free electrons generated during energy metabolism of anaerobes.
  • Thus, metronidazole is intrinsically resistant to aerobic bacteria such as bacillus.
  • Other uses of metronidazole include-
  1. Amoebic dysentery
  2. Giardiasis
  3. Bacterial vaginosis
  4. Tetanus

Reference:

Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 895

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma is treated with a chemotherapy regimen including 6-Mercaptopurine. Administration of which of the following agents would increase this patient's risk for mercaptopurine toxicity?
questions.solution:
• 6-mercaptopurine is degraded to an inactive metabolite by xanthine oxidase.
  • Allopurinol is an inhibitor of xanthine oxidase, thereby increasing mercaptopurine toxicity.
  • 6-mercaptopurine (6-MP) is a purine analog that inhibits de novo purine synthesis.
  • The drug is converted to an active metabolite by hypoxanthine guanine phosphoribosyl transferase (HGPRTase) in the purine salvage pathway.
  • The clinical usage of 6-MP includes treatment of leukemias, such as ALL, non-Hodgkins lymphoma, and immunosuppression.
  • Toxic side effects of 6-MP include GI disturbances, hepatotoxicity, and myelosuppression.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 922

choices.text: Start antibiotic therapy for H. pylori

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman with complaints of upper abdominal pain. Her symptoms started 1 month ago with vague abdominal discomfort following a meal. Since then, she felt the pain for more than 5 episodes. There is mild epigastric tenderness but no guarding and no rebound. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
• The patient is presenting with epigastric discomfort that is worse with eating and associated heartburn, which is consistent with dyspepsia and gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). The patient should begin omeprazole therapy.
  • Common causes of dyspepsia include GERD, NSAID use, symptomatic Heliobacter pylori, and gastric or esophageal cancer. Definitive diagnosis often requires an upper gastrointestinal endoscopy with biopsy, but young patients (< age 60) with typical GERD symptoms (e.g., heartburn) without alarm symptoms (e.g., weight loss, anemia, dysphagia, gross/occult bleeding, and early satiety) can first be managed with lifestyle changes and acid suppression for 6-8 weeks.
  • Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) such as omeprazole or histamine-2-receptor antagonists such as ranitidine can be used for acid suppression, but PPIs have better efficacy.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 700

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman at 16 weeks' gestation comes with nausea and recurrent burning epigastric discomfort for 1 month. Her symptoms are worse after heavy meals. Treatment with which of the following drugs should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
• The medication that should be avoided for treatment of this patient's dyspepsia is sometimes used off-label for cervix ripening and induction of labor.
  • Misoprostol is a prostaglandin analog (PGE1 analog) that can prevent NSAID-induced peptic ulcer formation by increasing the production of the gastric mucus barrier and decreasing gastric acid secretion.
  • Misoprostol is contraindicated during pregnancy because it is associated with an increased risk of abortion and congenital malformations.
  • Besides its off-label use for cervical ripening and labor induction, misoprostol can be used in combination with a progesterone antagonist for medical abortion.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 702

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with constipation for the last 6 days. He says that the constipation started 1 day after he started taking an over-the-counter medication for sinus congestion and a chronic cough. Which of the following drugs was most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Opioid antitussives

Morphine and its congeners are the most effective antitussives, but morphine is not suitable for treating cough, because of its strong addicting and respiratory depressant property.

Codeine

An opium alkaloid, qualitatively similar to and less potent than morphine, but is more selective for cough centre. Abuse liability is low, but present; constipation is the chief drawback. At higher doses respiratory depression and drowsiness can occur, especially in children.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 239

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents to your office with dyspnea, reporting nocturnal cough. You note expiratory wheezing on auscultation. Chest x-ray reveals increased anteroposterior diameter. Past medical history is significant for multiple episodes of self-diagnosed bronchitis as a child. Which of the following drugs would be most effective for long-term treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
• Budesonide is an inhaled corticosteroid (ICSs). ICSs are first-line, long-term treatment for the inflammatory component of asthma.
  • The inflammatory component of asthma is multicellular in nature; mast cells, neutrophils, eosinophils, T lymphocytes, and epithelial cells participate in the response. Moreover, the various mediators, cytokines, and chemokines from these cells contribute to the inflammatory process.
  • ICSs work by inducing apoptosis of these inflammatory cells, inhibiting the production of their cytokines, and decreasing mucus production by goblet cells. Although they do not have any direct bronchodilator effects, they have dramatic anti-inflammatory effects on the respiratory epithelium. ICSs are used in the prevention of acute exacerbations, but they do not have a role in treating acute episodes.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 251

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother. His mother reports that she found him playing under the sink yesterday, where she saw him playing with some rat poison, unsupervised. The boy has abdominal pain and epistaxis.
You obtain stat lab-work with the following results:
Platelets: 200,000/microL
PTT: 35 seconds
INR: 6.5
Which of the following is likely to be the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
• This boy has an elevated INR and epistaxis, likely due to Rat poison toxicity, which is similar to Warfarin (coumadin) in its effects. The appropriate treatment involves administration of Vitamin K and Fresh Frozen Plasma (FFP).
  • Anticoagulant rodenticides act in a mechanism similar to coumadin. These compounds inhibit vitamin K epoxide reductase (VKOR), thereby preventing gamma-carboxylation of clotting factors. The activation of clotting factors occurs primarily in the liver. The factors affected include factors II, VII, IX, X, protein C, and protein S. Existing clotting factors are not affected.
  • This boy's extremely elevated INR with approximately normal PTT suggests that he was in contact with a substance that affects the extrinsic coagulation cascade, such as warfarin.

Reference:

Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 659

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presents with complaints of left sided chest pain. The pain radiates to his left arm and stomach. He also complains of feeling anxious and heart palpitations. Cardiac catheterization reveals occlusion of the left anterior descending artery. The patient is discharged on aspirin, atorvastatin, and an antiplatelet medication. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of the most likely prescribed antiplatelet medication?
questions.solution:
• This patient with MI was most likely prescribed clopidogrel, which is an irreversible ADP receptor antagonist commonly used in the setting of PCI.
  • Under physiologic conditions, activated platelets will secrete ADP, which binds to ADP receptors (P2Y12) on other platelets, leading to GPIIb/IIIa activation and fibrinogen binding, resulting in clot formation.
  • Clopidogrel counters this via an irreversible blockade of ADP receptors. Because of this, clopidogrel is used after percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with stent placement.
  • Other examples of ADP receptor antagonists include ticlopidine and prasugrel.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 678

questions.text: A 55-year-old female with poorly controlled hyperlipidemia and obesity, reports that she feels well and has no complaints. Her total cholesterol is 290 mg/dl, triglycerides are 120 mg/dl, and LDL cholesterol is 215 mg/dl. Her physician considers starting her on a medication that forces the liver to consume cholesterol to make more bile salts. Which of the following adverse effects is this patient at highest risk of developing following initiation of the medication?
questions.solution:
• Cholestyramine is a bile acid sequestrant that has lipid-lowering effects by forcing the liver to create more bile salts. Gastrointestinal disturbances and fat malabsorption are adverse effects of bile acid sequestrants.
  • Bile acid sequestrants like cholestyramine and colestipol are a second-line class of lipid-lowering agents.
  • These medications bind bile acids in the intestine to prevent their reabsorption.
  • This forces the liver to consume additional cholesterol in the process of synthesizing new bile acids, thereby increasing LDL receptor synthesis.
  • Adverse effects of bile acid sequestrants include GI upset and malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins.
  • The first-line medication for patients with hyperlipidemia is a statin such as lovastatin or simvastatin.
  • Statins function by inhibiting HMG-CoA reductase, the rate-limiting enzyme in cholesterol synthesis.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 686-687

questions.text: A 59-year-old man is brought to the primary care clinic by his wife for recent behavioral changes. In the past 2 months, his wife has caught him stimulating his genitals in public on at least 5 separate occasions. Over the same time frame, he has also taken up online gambling and has lost a large sum of money. He denies any recent cognitive changes. His medical history includes hypertension for which he takes amlodipine. He was diagnosed with Parkinson disease 3 months ago and started on pramipexole. His fingers exhibit a slow tremor at rest. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• This patient's presentation with sudden behavioral changes that are indicative of impaired impulse control (hypersexuality and pathologic gambling) in the setting of the recent initiation of dopamine agonist therapy, pramipexole, suggests the development of an impulse control disorder. Impulse control disorders are a known side effect of dopamine agonist therapy.
  • There are 3 main dopaminergic pathways in the central nervous system, consisting of the nigrostriatal pathway, meso-corticolimbic pathway, and tuberoinfundibular pathway.
  • Parkinson's disease is caused by degeneration of the nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, dopamine agonists (e.g., pramipexole, ropinirole, or bromocriptine) are used in the initial treatment of Parkinson's disease, especially in younger patients. However, these drugs also activate the meso-corticolimbic pathway, which controls the reward system.
  • This agonism is thought to amplify existing behavioral tendencies, leading to compulsive reward-seeking behavior that can manifest as hypersexuality, pathologic gambling, and/or compulsive shopping.
  • Patients and caretakers should receive education on these potential side effects when dopamine agonist therapy is initiated. If an impulse control disorder develops, dopamine agonist therapy should be tapered until the impulse control disorder resolves.

Reference:

Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 452

questions.text: A 19-year-old man comes with a history of generalized tonic-clonic seizures. Oral examination shows marked overgrowth of friable, ulcerated gingival mucosa. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's oral examination findings?
questions.solution:
• Phenytoin is used in the prophylaxis of generalized tonic-clonic seizures, as seen in this patient. The agent has many side effects, including gingival hyperplasia (drug-induced gingival overgrowth), hirsutism, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, megaloblastic anemia, nystagmus, ataxia, and peripheral neuropathy.
  • If possible, the drug should be discontinued and the patient should be advised to adhere to strict oral hygiene. If the gingival overgrowth does not improve or infection occurs, excision of excessive gingival tissue should be considered.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 441

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of recurrent aspiration pneumonia is brought to the emergency department by his daughter after being found unconscious and gasping for air in his bed. Despite resuscitative efforts, the patient dies. Autopsy of the patient shows degeneration of the corticospinal tracts and anterior horn cells of the upper cervical cord. There is asymmetrical atrophy of the limb muscles, the diaphragm, and the intercostal muscles. Which of the following drugs would have most likely slowed the progression of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
• The autopsy findings of the upper (corticospinal tract) and lower motor neuron (anterior horn cells, muscle atrophy) degeneration indicate amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).
  • By blocking sodium channels, Riluzole exerts an anti-excitotoxic effect that causes the inhibition of glutamate in the CNS. In patients with ALS, this effect slows down the deterioration of motor function and thus increases life expectancy.

Reference: Goodman and Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 14th edition, page no. 422-423

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl undergoes an emergent appendectomy. She is given a mixture of nitrous oxide and sevoflurane for induction of anesthesia and intubated for a secure airway during surgery. A few minutes after induction, she is found to have increased end-tidal carbon dioxide and tachycardia. Finally, she is found to have hyperkalemia despite having normal serum potassium during preoperative laboratory studies. Defective function of which of the following proteins is most likely responsible for this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
• This patient who developed rigidity, tachycardia, hyperkalemia, and increased end-tidal carbon dioxide after induction of anesthesia most likely has malignant hyperthermia, which is caused by a mutation in the ryanodine receptor.
  • Inhaled anesthetic agents such as isoflurane and sevoflurane are widely used in the induction of anesthesia for surgery.
  • They have a wide variety of side effects including myocardial depression, respiratory depression, and increased cerebral blood flow. Susceptible patients can also experience cardiac arrhythmias, hepatotoxicity, nephrotoxicity, and malignant hyperthermia.
  • Malignant hyperthermia occurs in patients with a mutation in the ryanodine receptor that results in increased calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum.
  • These patients will develop fever, rigidity, tachycardia, hyperkalemia, and increased end-tidal carbon dioxide when exposed to inhaled anesthetic agents.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 406-408

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman, Bela delivers a newborn female infant. The child is in distress with neck veins distended and an enlarged v-wave. She has a holosystolic murmur. Her CXR is as follows. For which of the following conditions was the mother likely receiving treatment?
questions.solution:
• This infant is suffering from Ebstein's anomaly, often linked to the use of lithium during pregnancy. Lithium is commonly used for the treatment of bipolar disorder.
  • Ebstein's anomaly is one of the major cyanotic heart lesions and is characterized by apical displacement of the tricuspid valve leaflets, decreased right ventricular volume, and atrialization of the right ventricle.
  • The resultant tricuspid regurgitation results in the enlarged v wave. Echocardiography shows a delayed closure of the displaced tricuspid valve (tricuspid regurgitation).

Reference: Goodman and Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 14th edition, page no. 379

questions.text: A 23-year-old male, Siddhu presents with persistent penile erection for the last 6 hours. He recently began outpatient treatment for depression with associated insomnia. Which of the following is the most likely precipitating factor for priapism?
questions.solution:
• This patient presented with priapism following recent initiation of treatment for Depression with Insomnia. The most likely cause is the atypical antidepressant Trazodone.
  • Trazodone is an atypical antidepressant that commonly causes sedation. Thus, Trazodone is frequently used as part of therapy for depression associated with insomnia. A feared (and frequently tested) side effect of trazodone is priapism.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 490

choices.text: Changes the delta G of the reaction
Lowers the free energy of products

questions.text: In your peripheral tissues and lungs, carbonic anhydrase works to control the equilibrium between carbon dioxide and carbonic acid in order to maintain proper blood pH. Through which mechanism does carbonic anhydrase exert its influence on reaction kinetics?
questions.solution:
• Enzymes like carbonic anhydrase lower the energy of activation that is needed to initiate a reaction.
  • Biologic enzymes work as catalysts to increase the rate of reaction. They do this by lowering the activation energy needed to initiate the reaction.
  • This is usually performed by bringing the necessary reactants in close proximity to one another in the proper biologic conformation and increasing the stability of the transition state.
  • The delta G of the reaction governs the direction of equilibrium.
  • A negative delta G favors the creation of products, while a positive delta G favors the creation of reactants.

Reference:

Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 15

questions.text:
Data on the properties of drug X:
Weight: 100 kg
Dose provided: 1500 mg
Serum concentration 15 mg/dL
Bioavailability: 1
If the patient has a weight of 60 kg and the target serum concentration is 10 mg/dL, which of the following best represents the loading dose of drug X that should be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
• Calculating the loading dose of a drug can be performed by using the formula:
  • [Loading dose = intended serum concentration (Cp) x volume of distribution (Vd)/ bioavailability (F)].
  • The volume of distribution for the subject data provided is given by dividing dose provided by serum concentration (1500 mg / 15 mg/dL = 100 dL).
  • This can also be calculated to the identical value using the loading dose equation. Since the sample patient weighs 100 kg and the patient in the question weighs 60 kg with a similar body composition, it is reasonable to assume that the patient's volume of distribution is 60 dL.
  • The bioavailability (intravenous value of 1) and the intended serum concentration are provided in the question. Therefore, the loading dose is (10 mg/dL) * (60 dL/1) = 600 mg.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 41

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents with a 1-hour history of bruising and bleeding. He says that he fell and scraped his knee on the ground. Since then, he has been unable to stop the bleeding and has developed extensive bruising around the area. He has a history of GERD, hypertension, and atrial fibrillation for which he is taking an oral medication. He says that he recently started taking omeprazole for reflux. Which of the following processes is most likely inhibited in this patient?
questions.solution:
• This patient who takes Warfarin and presents with increased bleeding after starting Omeprazole most likely has inhibition of the Cytochrome P450 system that is responsible for oxidation of drugs.
  • Metabolism of compounds can be divided into phase I and phase II metabolism. Phase I metabolism involves oxidation, reduction, and hydrolysis reactions that together convert a parent drug into a more water-soluble metabolite. These reactions are performed by the cytochrome P450 complex, which can be inhibited by a large variety of compounds such as isoniazid, omeprazole, metronidazole, and grapefruit juice.
  • Warfarin is a classic example of a drug that is metabolized through phase I metabolism. In contrast, phase II metabolism involves conjugation reactions such as acetylation, glucuronidation, and sulfation.

    Reference:

    Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 28

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman presents with a 1-hour history of shortness of breath and chest pain. Her past medical history is significant for a previous deep venous thrombosis for which she was taking a blood thinner. She takes metformin, lisinopril, atorvastatin, carbamazepine and valproic acid as medications. Which of these drugs is most likely responsible for causing this patient's blood thinner medications to fail?
questions.solution:
• This patient who is experiencing pleuritic chest pain and shortness of breath most likely has a pulmonary embolism. Increased metabolism of warfarin due to P450 induction by carbamazepine would have predisposed this patient to a thromboembolism event.
  • The cytochrome P450 system is a group of liver enzymes that are responsible for the metabolism of diverse drugs. One of the most important drugs regulated by the P450 system is the blood thinner warfarin, which is often used for prophylaxis of thromboembolic events. P450 inducers will, therefore, increase the metabolism of warfarin and decrease drug effectiveness. In contrast, P450 inhibitors will increase circulating levels of warfarin that may result in bleeding events.
  • Relevant P450 inducers include St. John's wort, phenytoin, barbiturates, rifampin, griseofulvin, carbamazepine, efavirenz, modafinil, cyclophosphamide, and ethanol.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 670

questions.text: A 45-year-old man, Anuj is prescribed Metformin and presents to the emergency department several hours after his first dose of Metformin, with bilateral deep venous thromboses. Which of the following best describes this patient's drug reaction?
questions.solution:
• This patient who presents with bilateral deep venous thromboses after starting metformin has experienced an unpredictable drug reaction. These reactions are rare and specific to idiosyncratic factors.
  • Adverse drug reactions can be classified into type A or type B reactions based on multiple characteristics.
  • Type A reactions are predictable based on the safety analysis of phase II and phase III clinical trials.
  • These reactions are common, typically mild, and self-limited in nature.
  • They are also related to the drug's mechanism of action and therefore are dose-dependent. An example would be dry mouth with anticholinergic use. In contrast, type B reactions are unpredictable and very rare.
  • They are often severe and can be idiosyncratic based on unknown genetic or environmental predispositions.
  • They also typically have no relationship to the drug's mechanism of action or dose. An example of a type B reaction is aplastic anemia in chloramphenicol use.

Reference:

Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 92

questions.text: A 79-year-old man, Sushrut who was hospitalized for overnight monitoring after elective surgery, is found on morning rounds to be confused and disoriented. However, he was found to be delirious and agitated overnight. Therefore, he was given a dose of a drug that affects the opening frequency of a neuronal ion channel. During morning rounds, he is found to have weakness, tremors, uncoordinated muscle movements, blurred vision, and disorientation. Which of the following could be used to reverse the drug that was administered to this patient?
questions.solution:
• This patient who was found to be disoriented after receiving a drug that alters the frequency of neuronal ion channel opening most likely received a benzodiazepine. Benzodiazepine action can be reversed with flumazenil.
  • Benzodiazepines increase the frequency of chloride channel opening in neurons by binding to subunits of the gamma-aminobutyric acid receptor.
  • It can be used to treat anxiety, panic disorder, seizures, alcohol withdrawal, insomnia, and other disorders.
  • In high doses or in vulnerable patients, benzodiazepines can cause central nervous system depression, confusion, disorientation, and muscle tremors. Flumazenil is the reversal agent for benzodiazepine overdose.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 435

choices.text: Give activated charcoal and draw a serum acetaminophen level now
Give activated charcoal and draw a serum acetaminophen level in three hours
Give activated charcoal and test the urine for an acetaminophen level
Draw a serum acetaminophen level now

questions.text: A 21-year-old girl, Heena with a history of Major Depressive Disorder reports that she wanted to 'end it all' and swallowed a full bottle of acetaminophen. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
• Patients presenting less than four hours after ingestion of a large quantity of acetaminophen should receive activated charcoal. The first acetaminophen level should be drawn four hours after ingestion.
  • Metabolism of acetaminophen depletes glutathione and forms toxic metabolites that accumulate in the liver and cause necrosis. This effect is exacerbated by chronic alcohol, which induces formation of cytochrome P450 enzymes and accelerates the production of harmful metabolites. If acetaminophen ingestion occurred less than 4 hours ago, activated charcoal should be given to reduce absorption.
  • Serum acetaminophen levels should be drawn four hours after ingestion and the result should be applied to the Rumack-Matthew nomogram, which predicts the risk of hepatotoxic effects and guide therapy. N-acetylcysteine works as an antidote by regenerating glutathione and may be given at any time within the first 8 hours after ingestion without sacrificing efficacy.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 221

choices.text: Decrease proximal tubule reabsorption of urate

questions.text: One week ago, a 55-year-old man experienced severe right knee pain associated with redness and swelling. A joint aspiration was performed in the emergency department and revealed findings resembling the schematic in image under polarized light. He is started on long-term therapy with a drug that decreases the production of the molecule responsible for his underlying condition. What is the mechanism of this drug?
questions.solution:
• This patient's recent presentation to the emergency department with acute monoarticular arthritis associated with joint erythema and swelling and negatively-birefringent, needle-shaped crystals on arthrocentesis is indicative of an acute gout flare. Long-term treatment of gout includes allopurinol, which functions as an inhibitor of xanthine oxidase.
  • Gout is caused by hyperuricemia with resultant deposition of monosodium urate crystals into joints, causing arthritis.
  • Gouty arthritis characteristically presents as an acute monoarticular, inflammatory arthritis, commonly at the first metatarsophalangeal, ankle, or knee joints.
  • Synovial analysis classically reveals negatively-birefringent, needle-shaped crystals under polarized light.
  • Urate is produced in the purine catabolism pathway, where hypoxanthine is successively oxidized into xanthine and urate by the enzyme xanthine oxidase. Inhibitors of xanthine oxidase, such as allopurinol or febuxostat, decrease the production of urate via this pathway, thus reducing the risk of gout flares.
  • Xanthine oxidase inhibitors are considered first-line urate-lowering agents.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 233

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought after a motor vehicle collision. 2 years ago, while having a surgery, he began to experience severe muscle contractions and an increased body temperature. Based on this information, a different class of muscle relaxants are chosen for use during the upcoming surgery. If these agents needed to be reversed, the reversal agent should be administered with which of the following to prevent off-target effects?
questions.solution:
• This patient with a history of muscle rigidity and hyperthermia during surgery most likely had an episode of malignant hyperthermia and will therefore be administered a non-depolarizing agent. These agents are reversed using neostigmine and atropine should be administered simultaneously to prevent off-target muscarinic effects of neostigmine.
  • Muscle relaxants can either be depolarizing or nondepolarizing depending on the method of action.
  • Nondepolarizing agents of the curare class are competitive antagonists of the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor and work by preventing acetylcholine from leading to muscle depolarization at the muscular end-plate.
  • These agents can be reversed using acetylcholinesterase inhibitors (AChE-I), which prevent acetylcholine breakdown and increases its concentration in the synapse.
  • Notably, since AChE-I do not distinguish between nicotinic and muscarinic acetylcholine receptors, a muscarinic antagonist such as atropine should be administered as well to prevent off-target effects.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 380

questions.text: A 54-year-old male presents with 1 day history of severe headaches. His temperature is 100.1F, blood pressure is 190/90 mmHg, pulse is 60/min, and respirations are 15/min. He is started on a high concentration sodium nitroprusside infusion. His blood pressure eventually improves and his headache resolves, but he becomes confused and tachycardic. Labs reveal a metabolic acidosis. Which of the following is the best treatment?
questions.solution:
• The patient has been on a sodium nitroprusside infusion for two days, which can cause cyanide poisoning. The best treatment is sodium nitrite.
  • Sodium nitroprusside is commonly used for the treatment of hypertensive emergencies.
  • It contains five cyanide groups per molecule, and can lead to cyanide poisoning with prolonged infusions or at high concentrations.
  • Cyanide binds to the ferric ion and inhibits cellular respiration, leading to cytotoxic hypoxia.
  • Cyanide poisoning most commonly presents with headache, confusion and arrhythmias, though other organ systems can also be affected. Laboratory testing will show an anion gap metabolic acidosis.
  • Treatment options include sodium nitrite, sodium thiosulfate and hydroxocobalamin.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 591

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman comes for an itchy rash on her leg. Examination shows a linear, erythematous, maculopapular rash on the left lower extremity. Treatment with a drug is begun that is also effective for motion sickness. One hour later, she reports dry mouth. This adverse effect is most likely mediated through which of the following?
questions.solution:
• The patient's allergic rash was most likely treated with a first-generation antihistamine (e.g., diphenhydramine). These agents are also used in the treatment of motion sickness.
  • First-generation antihistamines, in addition to their H1-receptor antagonist action, also have potent acetylcholine receptor blocking action.
  • AChRs are part of the parasympathetic nerve supply of the body.
  • As saliva is secreted secondary to parasympathetic stimulation, antagonism at AChRs results in dry mouth, as seen in this patient.
  • Other common anticholinergic effects include decreased sweating, tachycardia (unopposed sympathetic activity on the heart), blurring of vision for near objects (loss of accommodation reflex and mydriasis), urinary retention and constipation (loss of parasympathetic-mediated sphincter relaxation and peristalsis), and drowsiness.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 180
